question: What am I, Mr. Lambert? How badly bitten, Mr. Frees?
answer: Aaagh! I can pay you!

question: When?
answer: Two weeks, three at the most, Aaaagh! For pity's sake.

question: Take his feet out. Where will you get including interest in three weeks?
answer: I have a wonderful new play!

question: Put his feet in.
answer: It's a comedy.

question: Cut his nose off.
answer: A new comedy. By Will Shakespeare!

question: And his ears.
answer: And a share. We will be partners, Mr. Fennyman!

question: Partners!
answer: It's a crowd-tickler--mistaken identities, a shipwreck, a pirate king, a bit with a dog, and love triumphant. This time it is by Shakespeare.

question: What's the title?
answer: Romeo and Ethel the Pirate's Daughter.

question: Good title. A play takes time. Find actors rehearsalslet's say open in three weeks. That's--what--five hundred groundlings at tuppence each, in addition four hundred groundlings tuppence each, in addition four hundred backsides at three pence--a penny extra for a cushion, call it two hundred cushions, say two performance for safety how much is that Mr. Frees? Correct!
answer: But I have to pay the actors and the authors.

question: A share of the profits.
answer: There's never any

question: Of course not!
answer: Mr. Fennyman, I think you may have hit on something.

question: Sign here. Romeo and Ethel The Pirate's DaughterAlmost finished?
answer: Without doubt he is completing it at this very moment. Will! Where is my play? Tell me you have it nearly done! Tell me you have it started. You have begun?

question: Without doubt he is completing it at this very moment. Will! Where is my play? Tell me you have it nearly done! Tell me you have it started. You have begun?
answer: Doubt that the stars are fire, doubt that the sun doth move

question: No, no, we haven't the time. Talk prose. Where is my play?
answer: It is all locked safe in here

question: God be praised! Locked?
answer: As soon as I have found my muse

question: Who is she this time?!
answer: She is always Aphrodite.

question: Aphrodite Baggot who does it behind the Dog and Trumpet?
answer: Henslowe, you have no soul so how can you understand the emptiness that seeks a soulmate?

question: Well, I am a dead man and buggered to boot. My theatre is close by the plague these twelve weeks, my company is playing the inn-yards of England, while Burbage and the Chamberlain's Men are invited to court and receive ten pounds to play your piece, written for my theatre, by my writer, at my risk when you were green and grateful -
answer: What piece? Richard Crookback?

question: No--it's comedy they want, Will! Comedy! Like Romeo and Ethel?
answer: Who wrote that?

question: Nobody! You are writing it for me! I gave you three pounds a month since.
answer: Half what you owed me. I am still due for One Gentleman of Verona.

question: . . . Will! What is money to you and me? I, your patron, you my wordwright! When the plague lifts Burbage will have a new Christopher Marlowe for the Curtain and I have nothing for the Rose.
answer: Mr. Henslowe, will you lend me fifty pounds?

question: Fifty pounds? What for?
answer: Burbage offers me a partnership in the Chamberlain's Men. For fifty pounds my hired player days are over.

question: Cut out my heart! Throw my liver to the dogs!
answer: No, then.

question: Where are you going?
answer: To my weekly confession. Words, words, wordsonce, I had the giftI could make love out of words as a potter makes cups out of clay love that overthrows empires, love that binds two hearts together come hellfire and brimstonesfor sixpence a line, I could cause a riot in a nunnerybut now

question: To my weekly confession. Words, words, wordsonce, I had the giftI could make love out of words as a potter makes cups out of clay love that overthrows empires, love that binds two hearts together come hellfire and brimstonesfor sixpence a line, I could cause a riot in a nunnerybut now
answer: And yet you tell me you lie with women? Black Sue, Fat Phoebe, Rosaline, Burbage's seamstress; Aphrodite, who does it behind the Dog and

question: Aye, now and again, but what of it? I have lost my gift.
answer: I am here to help you. Tell me in your own words.

question: I have lost my gift. It's as if my quill is broken. As if the organ of the imagination has dried up. As if the proud tower of my genius has collapsed.
answer: Interesting.

question: Nothing comes.
answer: Most interesting.

question: It is like trying to a pick a lock with a wet herring.
answer: Tell me, are you lately humbled in the act of love? How long has it been?

question: A goodly length in times past, but lately
answer: No, no. You have a wife, children

question: I was a lad of eighteen. Anne Hathaway was a woman, half as old again.
answer: A woman of property?

question: She had a cottage. One day, she was three months gone with child, so
answer: And your relations?

question: On my mother's side the Ardens
answer: No, your marriage bed.

question: Four years and a hundred miles away in Stratford. A cold bed too, since the twins were born. Banishment was a blessing.
answer: So now you are free to love

question: yet cannot love nor write it.
answer: Here is a bangle found in Psyche's temple on Olympus cheap at four pence. Write your name on a paper and feed it in the snake.

question: Will it restore my gift?
answer: The woman who wears the snake will dream of you, and your gift will return. Words will flow like a river. I will see you in a week.

question: To the Palace at Whitehall. Prithee, Mr. Kempe, break a leg. You too, good Crab. No, they would laugh at Seneca if you played it.
answer: My sleeve wants for a button, Mistress Rosaline, where were my seamstress's eyes? There is no dog in the first scene, Will Kempe, thank you. How goes it Will?

question: I am still owed money for this play, Burbage.
answer: Not from me. I only stole it. When are you coming over to the Chamberlain's Men?

question: When I have fifty pounds.
answer: Are you writing?

question: A comedy. All but done, a pirate comedy, wonderful.
answer: What is the chief part?

question: Romeo. Wit, swordsman, lover.
answer: The title?

question: Romeo
answer: I will play him. Bring it tomorrow.

question: It's for Henslowe. He paid me.
answer: How much?

question: Ten pounds.
answer: You're a liar.

question: I swear it. He wants Romeo for Ned and the Admiral's Men.
answer: Ned is wrong for it. Here is two sovereigns--I'll give you two more when you show me the pages.

question: When will you write me a sonnet, Will?
answer: I have lost my gift.

question: You left it in my bed. Come to look for it again.
answer: Are you to be my muse, ROSALINE?

question: Burbage has my keeping but you have my heart.
answer: You see? The consumptives plot against me. "Will Shakespeare has a play, let us go and cough through it." I feel a scene coming on.

question: Did you like Proteus or Valentine best? Proteus for speaking, Valentine for looks.
answer: I liked the dog, for laughs.

question: But Silvia I did not care for much. His fingers were red from fighting and he spoke like a schoolboy at lessons. Stage love will never be true love while the law of the land has our heroines played by pipsqueak boys in petticoats! Oh, when can we see another?
answer: When the Queen commands it.

question: But at the playhouse. Nurse?
answer: Be still. Playhouses are not for well-born ladies.

question: I am not so well-born.
answer: Well-monied is the same as well-born and well-married is more so. Lord Wessex was looking at you tonight.

question: All the men at court are without poetry. If they look at me they see my father's fortune. I will have poetry in my life. And adventure. And love. Love above all.
answer: Like Valentine and Silvia?

question: No . . . not the artful postures of love, but love that over- throws life. Unbiddable, ungovernable, like a riot in the heart, and nothing to be done, come ruin or rapture. Love like there has never been in a play. I will have love or I will end my days as a . . .
answer: As a nurse.

question: But I would be Valentine and Silvia too. Good Nurse, God save you and good night. I would stay asleep my whole life if I could dream myself into a company of players.
answer: Clean your teeth while you dream, then. Now spit

question: This time we take your boots off!
answer: What have I done, Mr. Fennyman?

question: The theatres are all closed by the plague!
answer: Oh, that.

question: by order of the Master of the Revels!
answer: Mr. Fennyman, let me explain about the theatre business. The natural condition is one of insurmountable obstacles on the road to imminent disaster. Believe me, to be close by the plague is a bagatelle in the ups and downs of owning a theatre.

question: So what do we do?
answer: Nothing. Strangely enough , it all turns out well.

question: How?
answer: I don't know. It's a mystery.

question: Yes I heard.
answer: If you wouldn't mind

question: Where is the play?
answer: Oh, it's coming, it's coming. Will! The theatres are

question: I would have made you immortal. Tell Burbage he has lost a new play by Will Shakespeare.
answer: What does Burbage care of that? He is readying the Curtain for Kit Marlowe.

question: You have opened the playhouses?
answer: I have, Master Shakespeare.

question: But the plague
answer: Yes, I know. But he was always hanging around the house.

question: Give me to drink mandragora. Kit
answer: How goes it, Will?

question: Wonderful, wonderful.
answer: Burbage says you have a play.

question: I have. And chinks to show for it. I insist--and a beaker for Mr. Marlowe. The BARMAN does the business. I hear you have a new play for the Curtain.
answer: Not new--my Doctor Faustus.

question: I love your early work. "Was this the face that launched a thousand ships and burnt the topless towers of Ilium?"
answer: I have a new one nearly done, and better. The Massacre at Paris.

question: Good title.
answer: And yours?

question: Romeo and Ethel the Pirate's Daughter. Yes, I know.
answer: What is the story?

question: Well, there's a pirate In truth, I have not written a word.
answer: Romeo isItalian. Always in and out of love.

question: Yes, that's good. Until he meets
answer: Ethel.

question: Do you think?
answer: The daughter of his enemy.

question: The daughter of his enemy.
answer: His best friend is killed in a duel by Ethel's brother or something. His name is Mercutio.

question: Tomorrow please God. Your name?
answer: Thomas Kent. I would like to do a speech by a writer who commands the heart of every player. "What light is light, if Silvia be not seen, What joy is joy, if Silvia be not by? Unless it be to think that she is by And feed upon the shadow of perfection. " except I be by Silvia in the night, There is no music in the nightingale. Unless I look on Silvia in the day, There is no day for me to look upon."

question: Take off your hat.
answer: My hat?

question: Where did you learn how to do that? Wait there.
answer: Are you Mr. Shakespeare?

question: Follow that boat!
answer: Right you are, governor! I know your face. Are you an actor?

question: Yes.
answer: Yes, I've seen you in something. That one about a king.

question: Really?
answer: I had the Christopher Marlowe in my boat once.

question: Do you know that house?
answer: Sir Robert De Lesseps.

question: The actor
answer: Who asks for him?

question: William Shakespeare, actor, poet, and playwright of the Rose.
answer: Master Kent ismy nephew.

question: I will wait.
answer: Much god may it do you.

question: Much god may it do you.
answer: He sees himself in me! Romeo Montague, a young man of Verona.

question: Verona again.
answer: A comedy of quarreling families reconciled in the discovery of Romeo to be the very same Capulet cousin stolen from the cradle and fostered to manhood by his Montague mother that was robbed of her own child by the Pirate King!

question: Your mother, and your father
answer: From tomorrow, away in the country for three weeks! Is Master Shakespeare not handsome?

question: He looks well enough for a mountebank.
answer: Oh, Nurse! He would give Thomas Kent the life of Viola De Lesseps's dreaming.

question: My lady, this play will end badly. I will tell.
answer: You will not tell. As you love me and as I love you, you will bind my breast and buy me a boy's wig!

question: Master Shakespeare
answer: My lady Viola.

question: My lord.
answer: I have spoken with your father.

question: So my lord? I speak with him every day. Good sir ? I heard you are a poet. But a poet of no words?
answer: "Poet?"

question: Christopher Marlowe at your service.
answer: Romeo, Romeo . . . a young man of Verona. A comedy. By William Shakespeare.

question: My lady!
answer: Who is there?

question: Will Shakespeare!
answer: Anon, good nurse. Anon. Master Shakespeare?!

question: The same, alas.
answer: Oh but why "alas?"

question: A lowly player.
answer: Alas indeed, for I thought you the highest poet of my esteem and a writer of plays that capture my heart.

question: Oh--I am him too!
answer: Anon, anon! I will come again.

question: Oh, I am fortune's fool, I will be punished for this! Oh my lady, my love!
answer: If they find you here they will kill you.

question: You can bring them with a word.
answer: Oh, not for the world! Anon, nurse!

question: Huzzah! The Admiral's Men are returned to the house!
answer: Who is this?

question: Silence, you god! I am Hieronimo! I am Tamburlaine! I am Faustus! I am Barrabas, the Jew of Malta--of yes, Master Will, and I am Henry VI. What is the play, and what is my part?
answer: A moment, sir!

question: Who are you?
answer: I am the money!

question: Then you may remain so long as you remain silent. Pay attention and you will see how genius creates a legend.
answer: Thank you, sir.

question: Mr. Pope! Mr. Phillips! Welcome, George Bryan! James Armitage! Sam! My pretty one! Are you ready to fall in love again?
answer: I am, Master Shakespeare.

question: But your voice Have they dropped?
answer: No, no, a touch of cold only. We suspect he is lying but WILL has turned away.

question: Master Henslowe, you have your actors.
answer: I saw his Tamburlaine, you know. Wonderful.

question: Yes, I saw it.
answer: Of course, it was mighty writing. There is no one like Marlowe

question: Better fortune, boy.
answer: I was in a play. They cut my head off in Titus Andronicus. When I write plays, they will be like Titus.

question: You admire it?
answer: I like it when they cut heads off. And the daughter mutilated with knives.

question: Oh. What is your name?
answer: Plenty of blood. That is the only writing. Wait, you'll see the cat bites his head off.

question: Cut round him for now.
answer: What? Who?

question: Romeo.
answer: The one who came with your letter?

question: "Good morrow, cousin."
answer: "Is the day so young?"

question: "But new struck nine."
answer: "Ay me, sad hours seem long. Was that my father that went hence so fast?"

question: It was. What sadness lengthens Romeo's hours?"
answer: "Not having that which, having, makes them short."

question: No, no, noDon't spend it all at once!
answer: Yes, sir.

question: Do you understand me?
answer: No, sir.

question: Two hours at prayer!
answer: Lady Viola is pious, my lord.

question: Piety is for Sunday! And two hours at prayer is not piety, it is self- importance!
answer: It would be better that you return tomorrow, my lord.

question: It would be better that you tell her to get off her knees and show some civility to her six-day lord and master. My lady VIOLA.
answer: Lord Wessex. You have been waiting.

question: I am aware of it, but it is beauty's privilege.
answer: You flatter, my lord.

question: No. I have spoken to the Queen. Her majesty's consent is requisite when a Wessex takes a wife, and once gained, her consent is her command.
answer: Do you intend to marry, my lord?

question: Your father should keep you better informed. He has bought me for you. He returns from his estates to see us married two weeks from Saturday. You are allowed to show your pleasure.
answer: I do not love you, my lord.

question: How your mind hops about! Your father was a shopkeeper, your children will bear arms, and I will recover my fortune. That is the only matter under discussion today. You will like Virginia.
answer: Virginia?!

question: Why, yes! My fortune lies in my plantations. The tobacco weed. I need four thousand pounds to fit out a ship and put my investments to work--I fancy tobacco has a future. We will not stay there long, three or four years . . .
answer: But why me?

question: It was your eyes. No, your lips. Will you defy your father and your Queen?
answer: The Queen has consented?

question: She wants to inspect you. At Greenwich, come Sunday. Be submissive, modest, grateful and brief.
answer: I will do my duty, my lord.

question: Gentlemen upstage, ladies downstage! Gentlemen upstage! Ladies downstage! Are you a lady, Mr. Kent?
answer: You did not like the speech?

question: The speech is excellent. "Oh, then I see Queen Mab hath been with you!" Excellent and a good length. But then he disappears for the length of a bible.
answer: There you have his duel, a skirmish of words and swords such as I never wrote, nor anyone. He dies with such passion and poetry as your ever heard

question: Row your boat. She tells me to keep away. She is to marry Lord Wessex. What should I do?
answer: If you love her, you must do what she asks.

question: And break her heart and mine?
answer: It is only ours you can know.

question: She loves me, Thomas!
answer: Does she say so?

question: No. And yet she does where the ink has run with tears. Was she weeping when she gave you this?
answer: I  Her letter came to me by the nurse.

question: Your aunt?
answer: Yes, my aunt. But perhaps she wept a little. Tell me how you love her, Will.

question: Like a sickness and its cure together.
answer: Yes, like rain and sun, like cold and heat. Is your lady beautiful? Since I came to visit from the country, I have not seen her close. Tell me, is she beautiful?

question: Oh, if I could write the beauty of her eyes! I was born to look in them and know myself.
answer: And her lips?

question: Oh, Thomas, her lips! The early morning rose would wither on the branch, if it could feel envy!
answer: And her voice? Like lark song?

question: Deeper. Softer. None of your twittering larks! I would banish nightingales from her garden before they interrupt her song.
answer: She sings too?

question: Constantly. Without doubt. And plays the lute, she has a natural ear. And her bosom--did I mention her bosom?
answer: What of her bosom?

question: Oh Thomas, a pair of pippins! As round and rare as golden apples!
answer: I think the lady is wise to keep your love at a distance. For what lady could live up to it close to, when her eyes and lips and voice may be no more beautiful than mine? Besides, can a lady born to wealth and noble marriage love happily with a Bankside poet and player?

question: Yes, by God! Love knows nothing of rank or riverbank! It will spark between a queen and the poor vagabond who plays the king, and their love should be minded by each, for love denied blights the soul we owe to God! So tell my lady, William Shakespeare waits for her in the garden!
answer: But what of Lord Wessex?

question: Can you love a fool?
answer: Can you love a player?

question: Wait! You are still a maid and perhaps as mistook in me as I was mistook in Thomas Kent.
answer: Answer me only this

question: I am.
answer: Then kiss me again for I am not mistook. I do not know how to undress a man.

question: I would not have thought it. There is something better than a play.
answer: There is.

question: Even your play.
answer: Oh

question: And that was only my first try.
answer: Well perhaps better than my first.

question: Will You would not leave me?
answer: I must. Look-- how pale the window.

question: Moonlight!
answer: No, the morning rooster woke me.

question: It was the owl--come to bed
answer: Oh, let Henslowe wait.

question: Mr. Henslowe?
answer: Let him be damned for his pages!

question: Oh--no, no!
answer: There is time. It is still dark.

question: It is broad day! The rooster tells us so!
answer: It was the owl. Believe me, love, it was the owl.

question: "Shall I hear more or shall I speak at this?"
answer: "What man art thou that thus bescreen'd in night So stumblest on my counsel?"

question: "By a name I know not how to tell thee who I am
answer: "The orchard walls are high and hard to climb, And the place death, considering who thou art, If any of my kinsmen find thee here. If they do see thee, they will murder thee."

question: "All my fortunes at thy foot I'll lay, And follow thee my lord throughout the world."
answer: "Madam!"

question: "I come, anon--But if thou meanest not well, I do beseech thee--"
answer: "Madam!"

question: NedI knowI know
answer: It's good.

question: Oh
answer: The title won't do.

question: Ah
answer: Romeo and Juliet--just a suggestion.

question: Thank you, Ned. You are a gentleman.
answer: And you are a Warwickshire shit-house.

question: You cannot! Not for the Queen herself!
answer: What will you have me do? Marry you instead?

question: To be the wife of a poor player?--can I wish that for Lady Viola, except in my dreams? And yet I would, if I were free to follow my desire in the harsh light of day.
answer: You follow your desire freely enough in the night. So, if that is all, to Greenwich I go.

question: Then I will go with you.
answer: You cannot, Wessex will kill you

question: I know how to fight!
answer: Stage fighting! Oh, Will! As Thomas Kent my heart belongs to you but as Viola the river divides us, and I will marry Wessex a week from Saturday.

question: Ah! My lady! The tide waits for no man, but I swear it would wait for you!
answer: Here we come at last, my lord!

question: Are you bringing your laundry woman?
answer: Her chaperone. My lady's country cousin. My, but you be a handsome gallant, just as she said! You may call me Miss Wilhelmina!

question: On a more fortuitous occasion, perhaps
answer: Oh, my lord, you will not shake me off, she never needed me more, I sear by your breeches!

question: Now? The Queen asks for you. Answer well. Is there a man?
answer: A man, my lord?

question: There was a man, poet--a theatre poet, I heard--does he come to the house?
answer: A theatre poet?

question: An insolent penny-a-page rogue, Marlowe, he said, Christopher Marlowe--has he been to the house?
answer: Marlowe? Oh yes, he is the one, lovely waistcoat, shame about the poetry.

question: Your Majesty.
answer: Stand up straight, girl. I have seen you. You are the one who comes to all the plays--at Whitehall, at Richmond.

question: Your Majesty.
answer: What do you love so much?

question: Your Majesty
answer: Speak out! I know who I am. Do you love stories of kings and queens? Feats of arms? Or is it courtly love?

question: I love theatre. To have stories acted for me by a company of fellows is indeed
answer: They are not acted for you, they are acted for me. And--?

question: And I love poetry above all.
answer: Above Lord Wessex? My Lord--when you cannot find your wife you had better look for her at the playhouse. But playwrights teach nothing about love, they make it pretty, they make it comical, or they make it lust. They cannot make it true.

question: What do you want, Kit?
answer: My Massacre at Paris is complete.

question: You have the last act?
answer: You have the money?

question: Tomorrow.
answer: Then tomorrow you will have the pages.

question: Wait! Will you desist!
answer: Twenty pounds on delivery

question: What is money to me like us? Besides, if I need a play, I have another waiting, a comedy by Shakespeare.
answer: Romeo?--he gave it to Henslowe.

question: Never!
answer: Well, I am to Deptford now, I leave my respects, Miss Rosaline.

question: I gave Shakespeare two sovereigns for Romeo!
answer: You did. But Ned Alleyn and the Admiral's Men have the playing of it as the Rose.

question: You look sad, my lady! Let me take you riding.
answer: It is not my riding day, my lord.

question: Bless me, I thought it was a horse.
answer: I am going to church.

question: I understand of course. It is to be expected.
answer: It is to be expected on a Sunday.

question: And on a day of mourning. I never met the fellow but once at your house.
answer: Mourning? Who is dead, my lord?

question: Oh!--dear God, I did not think it would be me to tell you. A great loss to playwriting, and to dancing.
answer: He is dead?

question: Will! Oh, my love, I thought you were dead!
answer: It is worse. I have killed a man. Marlowe's touch was in my Titus Andronicus and my Henry VI was a house built on his foundations.

question: You never spoke so well of him.
answer: He was not dead before. I would exchange all my plays to come for all of his that will never come.

question: You lie. You lie in your meadow as you lied in my bed.
answer: My love is no lie. I have a wife, yes, and I cannot marry the daughter of Sir Robert de Lesseps. It needed no wife come from Stratford to tell you that. And yet you let me come to your bed.

question: Calf love. I loved the writer, and gave up the prize for a sonnet.
answer: I was the more deceived. Now?

question: I love you, Will, beyond poetry.
answer: Oh, my love You ran from me before.

question: You were not dead before. When I thought you dead, I did not care about all the plays that will never come, only that I would never see your face. I saw our end, and it will come.
answer: You cannot marry Wessex!

question: If not Wessex the Queen will know the cause and there will be no more Will Shakespeare.
answer: Nono.

question: But I will go to Wessex as a widow from these vows, as solemn as they are unsanctified.
answer: For killing Juliet's kinsman Tybalt, the one who killed Romeo's friend Mercutio, Romeo is banished but the Friar who married Romeo and Juliet You, Edward. The Friar who married them gives Juliet a potion to drink. It is a secret potion. It makes her seeming dead. She is placed in the tomb of the Capulets. She will awake to life and love when Romeo comes to her side again. I have not said all. By malign fate, the message goes astray which would tell Romeo of the Friar's plan. He hears only that Juliet is dead. And thus he goes to the Apothecary.

question: The play. All written out for you. I had the clerk at Bridewell do it, he has a good fist for lettering. There's a new scene
answer: Will you read it for me?

question: "Wilt thou be gone? It is not yet near day> It was the nightingale and not the lark That pierced the fearful hollow of thine ear. Nightly she sings on yon pomegranate tree. Believe me, love, it was the nightingale."
answer: "It was the lark, the herald of the morn, No nightingale. Look, love, what envious streaks Do lace the severing clouds in yonder east. Night's candles are burnt out, and jocund day Stands tiptoe on the misty mountain tops. I must be gone and live, or stay and die."

question: "Yon light is not daylight, I know it, I. It is some meteor that the sun exhales To be to thee this night a torchbearer" "thou need'st not to be gone."
answer: "I have more care to stay than will to go. Come death, and welcome. Juliet wills it so. How is't my soul? Let's talk. It is not day."

question: Master of the Revels, sir, over here, sir.
answer: Where, boy?

question: I saw her bubbies!
answer: A woman on the stage? A woman?

question: I swear it!
answer: So, Henslowe! I say this theatre is closed! On the authority of the powers invested in my by the court--I close this theatre!

question: We are lost.
answer: No, it will turn out well.

question: How will it?
answer: I don't know, it's a mystery.

question: Master Shakespeare
answer: Luck be with you, Sam. Sam?

question: It is not my fault, Master Shakespeare. I could do it yesterday.
answer: Sam! Do me a speech, do me a line.

question: Another little problem.
answer: What do we do now?

question: The show must  you know
answer: Go on.

question: Juliet does not come on for twenty pages. It will be all right.
answer: How will it?

question: No Juliet?!
answer: it will be all right, madam.

question: What happened to Sam?
answer: Who are you?

question: Thomas Kent!
answer: Do you know it?

question: I arrest you in the name of Queen Elizabeth!
answer: Arrest who, Mr. Tilney?

question: Everybody! The Admiral's Men, The Chamberlain's Men and everyone of you ne'er-do-wells who stands in contempt of the authority invested in me by her Majesty.
answer: Contempt? You closed the Rose--I have not opened it.

question: Master Shakespeare. Next time to you come to Greenwich, Come as yourself and we will speak some more. WILL bows deeply. The QUEEN turns to leave. The waves part for her.
answer: Your Majesty!

question: Why, Lord Wessex! Lost your wife so soon?
answer: Indeed I am a bride short. How is this to end?

question: As stories must when love's denied--with tears and a journey. Those whom God has joined in marriage, not even I can put asunder. Lord Wessex, as I foretold, has lost his wife in the play- house--go make your farewell and send her out. It's time to settle accounts. How much was the wager?
answer: Fifty shillings. Pounds.
